Participants.evidence: primary, isolated multi-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting with the left internal thoracic artery, and who received a second arterial conduit (right internal thoracic artery or radial artery, N=5,866) or a venous conduit (N=53,566) between 2006 and 2011.

Intervention.evidence: who received a second arterial conduit (right internal thoracic artery or radial artery, N=5,866) or a venous conduit (N=53,566)

Objective.evidence: Whether a second arterial conduit improves outcomes after multi-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting remains unclear.

Method_Outcome.evidence: we compared all-cause mortality and rates of stroke, myocardial infarction, repeat revascularization, and sternal wound infection

Number_Randomised.evidence: N=5,866) or a venous conduit (N=53,566) between 2006 and 2011.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Propensity score matching using 34 preoperative characteristics yielded 5,813 matched sets.

Result_Outcome.evidence: receipt of a second arterial conduit was associated with significantly lower mortality (13.1% vs. 10.6% at 7 years; HR 0.79, 95% CI 0.72–0.87), and lower risks of myocardial infarction (HR 0.78, 95% CI 0.70–0.87) and repeat revascularization (HR 0.82, 95% CI 0.76–0.88).

Harms.evidence: but the risk of sternal wound infection was increased (risk difference 1.07%, 95% CI 0.15%–2.07%).
